text:
There’s not much that can top a big bowl
of spaghetti and meatballs.

Except for, of course, for what belongs on
top: parmesan cheese.

But, it turns out, what we’re eating might
not be parmesan at all.

Stay tuned to learn how chemists are fighting
faux fromage and other phony foods.

A lot of cheese labeled 100% grated parmesan
just isn’t.

The FDA recently found that several sellers
in the U.S. were filling out their batches

by putting in lower-cost cheeses or even cellulose,
also known as wood pulp, which adds fiber

and prevents clumping.The CEO of a Pennsylvania
cheese company just pled guilty to doing so,

and that big cheese faces up to six-figures
in fines or even prison time.
But that’s an extreme case.

Many of the parmesan imposters are guilty
of a more semantic crime.

Over in Italy, regulators dictate that real
parmesan--or parmigiano reggiano--must

be made from unpasteurized milk from cows
in specific Italian provinces.

And those cows can’t be fed fermented grasses
called silage according to the Parmigiano-Reggiano

Cheese Consortium -- yes, that’s a real
thing.

That’s because silage can contain Clostridium
bacteria, which produce unwanted gas and therefore
defects during the cheese-ripening stage.
So how can we tell if it’s legit?

Recently, a team of chemists at the University
of Parma -- obviously -- discovered that milk

and cheese from cows fed silage contained
small amounts of two unusual cyclopropane
fatty acids, or CPFAs.

The team then used the analytical technique
gas chromatography/mass spectrometry to look

for these two culprits in more than 300 cheese
samples.
Sure enough, their test worked.

Cheeses like parmigiano reggiano, fontina,
and gruyere -- that come from cows not fed
silage -- didn’t have these CPFAs.

But grana padano, a hard cheese from cows
that eat silage and one that’s often sneakily

mixed in with parmesan, did have these specific
CPFAs.

So if a parmesan sample has these fatty acids,
it can be flagged as counterfeit or not 100%
real parmesan.

And it’s not just the parmesan on your pasta
that’s sometimes fake.

Olive oil fraud is rampant, because it’s
much more valuable than other vegetable oils
and it’s easy to fake.

Although E.U. law dictates that extra-virgin
oil must meet 32 chemical requirements, fraudsters

can often dilute olive oil with cheaper hazelnut,
soybean, or seed oils.

The E.U. anti-fraud office has it’s own
olive-oil task force, but the U.S. FDA has
thrown its hands up and doesn’t even check.

But c’mon, what’s the big deal if we want
to have some spaghetti aglio e olio with our

multi-vegetable olive oil and parmesan-ish
cheese?

Well, food mislabeling has caused such an
international uproar that a global

trade treaty is being delayed by angry European
cheese makers, along with other protesters.
Ok, so kind of a big deal.

What’s an even bigger deal in food authentication
is making sure that products don’t have bacterial

contaminants or unwanted allergens, like nuts
and seafood.

This is extremely hard because food has tons
of different ingredients and comes in all

sorts of physical forms -- think tomato sauce
versus graham crackers versus steak -- so

a single method has no hope of working for
all foods.
But there are some testing staples.

Mass spectrometry is often used to look for
pesticides, antibiotics, or specific unwanted
chemical compounds.

For detecting bacteria like E. Coli or Salmonella,
labs can use the polymerase chain reaction,

or PCR, which multiplies DNA segments to look
for genetic signatures of contamination.

PCR can also be used to test for geographic
origin by comparing the DNA in food to the

DNA of plants and animals in the region the
food supposedly came from.

So it could be used to determine that your
parmesan cheese comes from the correct regions in Italy.

But PCR is tough to run on food because how
a food gets processed--baked, steamed, shredded,
or otherwise--can mess with its DNA.

Ingredients like calcium can also inhibit
the enzymes needed for PCR to run.

So researchers are hard at work developing
other techniques to catch counterfeit or contaminated food.

At the same time, officials are fighting outside
the lab about who gets to label their cheese
parmesan or their olive oil extra virgin.

But I think we can all agree that making sure
food doesn’t have bad bacteria or unlabeled

allergens is a great thing, so let’s toast
to that...

With some lovely bubbly. Because yes, you
guessed it, EU regulators say it should only

be called Champagne when it’s made from
grapes grown in the Champagne region of France.
